content.description: Start standing. Find the crimps on the upside down rail. Work your way up and right to the big jug. Arete is off.
content.location: On the Black Diamond boulder up the hill from the prow. Left side of the slab portion.

content.description: Start sitting with a great left hand jug and a vertical crimp. Pull up and follow the arete up to the crack and topout.
content.location: Located on the Black Diamond Boulder up the hill from the prow.

content.description: On the left side of the black diamond boulder is a slab problem. Not amazing but very thin feeling. A hard start low on the boulder to just get grip. Then foot too hand match stand up using balance on a tiny chip to a few dimples too work your way up tend too the right side as the left is alot easier
content.location: walk up the hill on your right once you get too the prow on your left. Its up there but may take some looking. If you see the quarry you went too far past the prow.

content.description: Start with left hand on a slight creator and right hand is sort of just smearing. Foot hand match the left hand hold. It is delicate to stand up on but good once you are up and can smear it. Once you've gotten this move and your standing use tiny features and smearing your feet too work right. And up to the top. Hardest part is standing up off of the foot hand match
content.protection: A pad or too it is not a bad fall.
content.location: This is on the what I call the black diamond boulder. If you pass the first boulders on the left of the trail. Continue walking maybe 20 ft. Turn right. And bush whack up the hill in a straight line. When you see the boulder you will know why it's called the black diamond boulder. It really looks like the logo.

content.description: A lonely but nice quality boulder. Fairly good landings. Named for its resemblance to the BD logo.
